Problem:
Consider the function \\( z(t) = e^{i \omega t} \cdot z_0 \\), where \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit, \\( \omega \\) is a constant, and \\( z_0 \\) is a complex number representing an initial value in the complex plane. This scenario deals with the evolution of the complex function over time and explores the possible effects of external complex transformations.

If \\( z(t) = e^{i \omega t} \cdot z_0 \\) evolves from \\( t = 0 \\) to \\( t = T \\) without any external transformation, will adding an initial phase shift \\( \phi \\) to \\( z_0 \\) at \\( t = 0 \\) result in the same \\( z(T) \\) regardless of the phase shift?
Explanation: The initial phase shift changes the starting direction of rotation in the complex plane. As \\( z(T) = e^{i \omega T} \cdot e^{i \phi} \cdot z_0 \\), this results in a different endpoint due to the shift \\( e^{i \phi} \\), leading to a different value of \\( z(T) \\) dependent on \\( \phi \\).
